newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli opposition head rules out unity government.
newsitem.headline: Israeli opposition head rules out unity government.

text.p: Israeli opposition leader Shimon Peres ruled out on Saturday a national unity government following a police recommendation to indict Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a government corruption scandal.
"As the situation stands today, there is no basis for a national unity government," the head of the Labour party told Israel Army radio.
Israel's attorney-general is expected to announce on Sunday whether Netanyahu and three other top officials will be indicted as recommended by police earlier in the week.

An indictment against Netanyahu, the first for an Israeli prime minister, could topple his government. Prosecutors could ignore the police recommendations made after a probe over a failed appointment in January of an attorney-general.
Peres, who helped engineer the PLO peace deals but lost last year's election to Netanyahu, has said in the past he would consider joining a national unity government.
Peres believes a unity government is the only way to save faltering Israeli peace moves with the Palestinians and other Arab partners.
"If the conclusions are that this government stays put then in my opinion the peace process will have almost lost its chance," Peres said.
